Among these are the recalcitrant and the fearful.
More than this, we must demonstrate to the community
at large, to the middle class and affluent sectors
of the community, that their stake in this effort is
an important as our concern. Organized Labor, long
the champion of the underpriveleged in our society,
must be made to understand that preparing the poor
and disadvantaged for useful and constructive
work is as much their problem, as it is our concern.
That "token" efforts are not enough. That money,
alone, is not enough. That one question remains
unanswered. How do we answer the poor when they
are barred from Organized Labor, once they have
acquired those job skills and come to realize that
Organized Labor has not provided for an effective
bridge into a constructive, contributive way of
life? No matter what we do, or how well we do
it, those restrictive conditions do exist in the
larger, working world. Among the minority populaÂ¬
tions such conditions serve only to reinforce those
feelings of inadequacy and lack of worth, feelings
which we have worked hard to overcome and to dispel.
This, too, is a problem in communication.
